title: Ewan McGregor admits 'it was embarrassing lying' about his new Star Wars series for four years
text:
He's going to reprise his role as Obi-Wan Kenobi in a TV series for new streaming channel Disney+.

But Ewan McGregor has admitted it was hard having to lie about his planned role for the four years the show spent in development.

Talking to Howie Mandel, who covered for Ellen DeGeneres on her chatshow on Tuesday, he explained: 'It's awkward.'

Kept it secret: Ewan McGregor admits 'it was embarrassing lying' about his new Star Wars series for four years as he appears on the Ellen Show on Tuesday; he was interviewed by Howie Mandel, filling in for Ellen

Original role: He's going to reprise his role as Obi-Wan Kenobi in a TV series for new streaming channel Disney+

Ewan continued: 'The studio and the franchises, they want to keep everything totally secret, of course which I understand but as the person being asked over and over and over again, "Would you do it again?"

'And I'm already talking to them about it but I can't say that I am.'

So for four years I was saying, "Well I'd be happy to do it again! I'm just waiting for the call." But all the while, it was embarrassing! Lying!'

The 48-year-old actor will reprise his role as the wise Jedi master in the untitled project.

Secrets: Talking to Howie, he explained: 'It's awkward.'

Star Wars plans: The 48-year-old actor will reprise his role as the wise Jedi master in the untitled project

The series - which will consist of six hour-long episodes - will air on Disney+ with production beginning in summer 2020.

It was finally confirmed by Lucasfilm at the Disney D23 Expo in August, after rumours being denied for a long time.

The highly anticipated show will be directed by Deborah Chow, who has worked on some episodes of another 'Star Wars' spin-off series, The Mandalorian.

McGregor, who played the Jedi in the prequel trilogy, previously revealed the show will see Obi-Wan deal with the fallout from his friend Anakin Skywalker turning to the Dark Side of The Force and becoming Darth Vader and the mass extermination of the Jedi at his hands on behalf of the Emperor.

Next up: First Ewan can be seen in The Shining's much-anticipated sequel Doctor Sleep

Ewan also revealed that he wanted his portrayal of Obi-Wan to be similar to that of Sir Alec Guinness, who played the character in the original trilogy.

He told Men's Health: 'I want to get closer and closer to how Obi-Wan felt while Alec Guinness was playing him. I feel like I'm greyer and nearer him in age, so it'll be easier to do that.'
